list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The system of equations given below represents three planes in space.
$$$x+5z−2x+y−6z2y+8z​=2=−1=6​$$$


Show that this system of equations has an infinite number of
solutions. [3]



Find the parametric equations of the line of intersection of the
three planes. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/d7ebb5d4-b295-4302-9567-a2e1473a7ad9/e92843ccd123af5e4a99f63d9b0726fa3e606968.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/033e32bc-f2d9-4a59-9060-bff7fcf72d3d/e2d7661b43a236c006ef48f0c2b01b8969087034.svg)


The last row of zeros tells us that the system is consistent. As there are only two pivot positions corresponding to $x$ and $y$, the variable $z$ is free. Hence the system has an infinite number of solutions.


We have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/a24bb1ff-e239-489e-9468-bac7261a87fe/9e7ed3301e98f940e211c9d9825320385d1b6446.svg)


If we express $x$ and $y$ in term of $z=t$, we obtain $x=2−5t$
and $y=3−4t$.
Hence the parametric equations of the line of intersection of the
$3$ planes are
$$$x=2−5t,y=3−4t,z=t​​$$$
where $t∈R$.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Consider the following system of equations:
$$$x−3z−3x+y+6z2x−2y+(a−4)z​=−2=3=b−3​$$$
where $a,b∈R$.


Find conditions on $a$ and $b$ for which


the system has no solutions;


the system has only one solution;


the system has an infinite number of solutions. [6]





In the case where the number of solutions is infinite, find the
general
solution of the system of equations in Cartesian form. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/8d98a020-29c7-478a-a0bb-6bf878fd5365/fc1722646826b747a78d8a717d7f3e24269c7335.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/31a4e0fb-271e-49aa-a81e-3bd96631488b/d5e5b20529826e7a89602916ebcc5c019737e1ea.svg)




![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/bf77797d-a060-4bd4-9a53-e06213ae845f/846a88889458337ab2aeba1c647b2fdea4de2812.svg)


The system has no solutions if


$a=4 and b=5​$


The system has only one solution if


$a=4 and b∈R​$


The system has an infinite number of solutions if


$a=4 and b=5​$




For $a=4$ and $b=5$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/e3231ca7-c35c-4f15-a847-afac67f27a47/8dacc6559227ad5fef6e1aeaeb78b17ac463976c.svg)


Hence the general solution of the system of equations in Cartesian
form is
$$$3x+2​=3y+3​=z​$$$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Consider the following system of equations:
$$$x+y+4z3x+2y+16z4x+2y+(a−1)z​=1=5=b−4​$$$
where $a,b∈R$.


Find conditions on $a$ and $b$ for which


the system has no solutions;


the system has only one solution;


the system has an infinite number of solutions. [6]





In the case where the number of solutions is infinite, find the
general
solution of the system of equations in Cartesian form. [3]
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/5638940f-c801-4755-8b7d-52ae2b81766d/71754659bebe16a79ad946ef4aafc3d04e0565c7.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/cb906fce-0828-4c2b-84ae-93973ebbdb34/038e3e50a616d564956e685040a3632159834164.svg)




![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/068d63d4-4bbe-4375-b74d-bf683839e578/87fa5baaa0e247b59e3412d3ed2d320e73681f15.svg)




The system has no solutions if
$a=25 and b=12​$


The system has only one solution if
$a=25 and b∈R​$


The system has an infinite number of solutions if
$a=25 and b=12​$




For $a=25$ and $b=12$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/a07b136b-b0df-49ac-ba53-56744d53d569/6539968a8c5ba7b87ecfd3a27ed70dbb2c225401.svg)


Using the method of back-substitution, we obtain
$$$−y+4zy​=2=4z−2​$$$
and
$$$x+(4z−2)+4zx​=1=3−8z​$$$
Hence the general solution
of the system of equations in Cartesian form is
$$$83−x​=4y+2​=z​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Consider the following system of equations:
$$$x+y+z4x+2y+z9x+3y​=−1=3=p​$$$
where $p∈R$.


Show that this system does not have a unique solution for any value
of $p$. [4]





Determine the value of $p$ for which the system is consistent.


For this value of $p$, find the general solution of the system.
[4]
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/f0382b32-b21c-4ba1-a0f5-4a79c36ddd6f/9f7fa9719e458a709cb1464a249710dcc108a8a6.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/bc6d005c-16b0-433a-b016-6a14a5666e85/ba6fbb5338a0222b47ef58fe6256b45e3ba64074.svg)


If $p=12$, the system is inconsistent and has no solutions. For otherwise, the~system is consistent and $z$ is a free variable. Hence, for any given value of $p$, the system either has no solutions or it has infinite number of solutions.




$p=12​$


For $p=12$, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/c2f1ebf4-8bb7-48ae-a3f9-7516a74cb2b0/bd86febfa147c1cf21b65e965d8b671ce0dbd029.svg)


Letting $z=t$ and using the method of back-substitution, we
obtain
$$$−2y−3z−2y−3ty​=7=7=−27​−23t​​$$$
and
$$$x+y+zx+[−27​−23t​]+tx​=−1=−1=25​+2t​​$$$
Hence the general solution of the system in parametric form is
$$$​x=25​+2t​,y=−27​−23t​,z=t​​$$$
where $t∈R$.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Consider three planes represented by the following system of equations:
$$$Π1​:−2x+ay+4zΠ2​:x+by−2zΠ3​:2x−y+cz​=2=−1=3​$$$
Where $a,b,c∈R$.


State the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$ for which


The system has infinite solutions.


The system is inconsistent. [7]





In the case where the system has infinite solutions, describe the geometric relationship between the three planes. [2]



In the case where the system is inconsistent, identify one of the geometric relationships that could exist between the three planes.  [2]
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented matrix, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/3f804c21-6625-4b1d-a6cc-56f4ed650a1e/aa1012a.PNG)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/da6543cf-8657-43e1-8040-dec0d15cf8cf/aa1012b.PNG)




From row 2, if the system has infinite solutions, we must have $a+2b=0$.
This implies that if $a=−2b$, there are infinite solutions to the system.
However, we also note from row 3, that if $a−1=0$ and $c+4=0$, then the system is inconsistent. In this case we have $a=1$ and $c=−4$.
There are infinite solutions to the system if $a=−2b$, $c∈R$ unless $a=1$, $b=−0.5$ and $c=−4$.


As noted in part (i), if $a=1$ and $c=−4$, the system is inconsistent.
However, we also note that if $a=1$ and $c=−4$, Gaussian Elimination leads to


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/7cd78d6b-425a-48e9-b2b6-e41b3b6fdb70/aa1021b.png)


In this case, we can also have an inconsistent system.
From part (a), if $a=−2b$ then the system is consistent (has infinite solutions), however consider when $a=−2b$.
It follows that $a+2b=k$, where $k=0$, this leads to


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/757dcf45-e7bd-4832-b55b-c311d8f0a8d8/aa1012a2.png)


Using row 2
$$$kyAs k=0 theny​=0=0​$$$
Using row 3, this value of $y$ shows an inconsistency as shown below.
$$$(a−1)y(a−1)×00​=5=5=5​$$$
Hence...
$The system is inconsistent if a=1 and c=−4,b∈R or if a=1,a=−2b and c=−4.​$




From (a) (i), we note that $Π1​$ is a multiple of $Π2​$. They are therefore equations representing the same plane.
$Π1​ and Π2​ are coincidental, Π3​ intersects both planes in a straight line.​$


In total there are 4 different geometric realtionships between the planes when the system is inconsistent.
First, from part (a) (i) we note that the system is inconsistent if $a=1$, $b=−0.5$ and $c=−4$. In this case,
$Π1​ and Π2​ are coincidental and Π3​ is parallel to both planes.​$
Second, from (a) (ii), we have one scenario where $a=1$, $b=−0.5$ and $c=−4$. In this case,
$Π1​ and Π3​ are parallel and Π2​ intersects both planes.​$
Thirdly, if $a=1$, $b=−0.5$ and $c=−4$,
$Π2​ and Π3​ are parallel and Π1​ intersects both planes.​$
Finally, if $a=1$, $a=−2b$ and $c=−4$, then $Π1​$ intersects $Π2​$ on a line, $Π1​$ intersects $Π3​$ on a different line and $Π2​$ intersects $Π3​$ on another different line. Additionally,$All three of these lines of intersection are parallel.​$
